courses.name: Introduction to Biological Engineering
courses.description: For first semester engineering students. Develop appreciation for professional engineering. Students will participate with senior design students to conceptualize a case-study problem.

courses.name: Professional Development in Engineering
courses.description: A review of professional opportunities, registration, ethics, and societies.

courses.name: Introduction to Programming for Engineers
courses.description: This course teaches how to write scientific programs for analysis of data and simulation of physical phenomena using Matlab. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis of Bioprocesses
courses.description: Material and Energy Balances.  Integrating principles of physics, chemistry and mathematics to analyze steady state and transient biological/biomedical processes. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1700, CHEM 1320, PHYSCS 2750. Restricted to Biological Engineering students only

courses.name: Topics in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Current and new technical developments in biological engineering.

courses.name: Environmental Control for Biological Systems
courses.description: Systems for controlling the physical environments (heat, moisture, light, contaminating organism, chemicals) for plant and animal systems including livestock, aquacultures, crops and agricultural products.

courses.name: Biological Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: Basic principles of fluid mechanics applied to transport processes in biological systems.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Materials Engineering
courses.description: Course covers concepts and techniques in materials engineering from an engineering design perspective, materials requirements for design, and fundamentals; intended for undergraduate engineering students. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300, ENGINR 1200Corequisites: One of the following BIOL_EN 3180, CH_ENG 3261, MAE 4231, MAE 4300, or instructor consent

courses.name: Biomaterials
courses.description: Engineering sciences and design will be leverage for the study and design of biomaterials.  Understanding the structure-property relationship between biomaterials and tissue will be addressed for implant design.

courses.name: Biomaterials - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Engineering sciences and design will be leverage for the study and design of biomaterials.  Understanding the structure-property relationship between biomaterials and tissue will be addressed for implant design.

courses.name: Heat and Mass Transfer in Biological Systems
courses.description: Principles of heat and mass transfer and their applications in biomedical, bioenvironmental, and bioprocessing engineering.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Current and new technical developments in biological engineering.

courses.name: Bioelectricity
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7070). Application of engineering approaches to understand bioelectricity at the cellular level including the equivalent circuit of cell membranes and the electronic design of patch-clamp amplifiers.

courses.name: Engineering Computation
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7080). An introduction to numerical methods relevant to biological engineering in the context of scientific computing. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Supervised independent study at the undergraduate level.

courses.name: Soil and Water Conservation Engineering
courses.description: (same as CV_ENG 4710; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7150, CV_ENG 7710).  Urban and rural run-off and erosion analysis.  Design and layout of erosion control structures.

courses.name: Food Process Engineering
courses.description: (cross_leveled with BIOL_EN 7160). Study of transport phenomena and unit operations in food processing systems. Emphasis on fluid flow and heat transfer in food processing, preservation processes, refrigeration, freezing, psychrometrics, and dehydration.

courses.name: Biomaterials Interfaces of Implantable Devices
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7170). Surface structures and properties to improve biocompatibility will be studied.  Engineering sciences and design will be leverage in the design of an improved biocompatible surface.

courses.name: Transport Phenomena in Materials Processing
courses.description: (same as MAE 4231; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7231, MAE 7231).  Applications of fluid flow, heat transfer, and mass transfer in steady-state and unsteady-state materials processing with applications to metals, polymers, and ceramics.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Irrigation and Drainage Engineering
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7250). Soil, water, plant relationships. Water supplies and design of surface, sprinkler and drip irrigation systems. Surface and tile drainage.

courses.name: Food Process Engineering II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7260). Continuing study of transport phenomena and unit operations in food processing systems. Emphasis on fluid food evaporation concentration food dehydration, contact equilibrium processes and mechanical separation processes.

courses.name: Design of Experiments and Statistical Quality Control for Process Engineers
courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 4270; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7270, CH_ENG 7270).  A practical statistical tool box for experimenters including comparison of process means, effects of variables, design and interpretation of factorial experiments, and statistical quality control.
courses.recommendation: experience with Excel or instructor's consent

courses.name: Survey of Bioengineering Techniques
courses.description: Laboratory techniques to train students in Bioelectricity, Biomechantronics, Bioenvironment, Biomaterials, Biophotonics, Bioprocessing.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Feedback Control Systems
courses.description: (same as ECE 4310, MAE 4750; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7310, ECE 7310, MAE 7750). System modeling and time and frequency response, closed loop control, stability, continuous system design, introduction to descrete time control, software and hardware experiments on compensator design and PID control.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Bioprocess Engineering
courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 4315; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7315, CH_ENG 7315).  This general introduction to bioprocess engineering covers the fundamentals of microbiology and biochemistry in the context of a biomass refinery.  Analyses proceed through the use of mass balances, energy balances, and empirical or theoretical models.
courses.recommendation: BIOL_EN 2180 (for Biological Engineering students) or CH_ENG 2225 (for Chemical Engineering students)

courses.name: Biomass Refinery Operations
courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 4316; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7316, CH_ENG 7316).  Design and operation of processes for conversion and/or fractionation of biomass and associated upstream and downstream unit operations.  Emphasis on separations and product recovery.
courses.recommendation: BIOL_EN 2180 or CH_ENG 2225 (for Chemical Engineering students) or  instructor's consent

courses.name: Watershed Modeling Using GIS
courses.description: (same as CV_ENG 4720; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7350, CV_ENG 7720).  Watershed evaluation using AVSWAT for hydrology, sediment yield, water quality; includes USLE, MUSLE, WEPP. Procedures for model calibration/sensitivity data analysis.
courses.recommendation: BIOL_EN 2180 or CV_ENG 3200 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Orthopaedic Biomechanics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7370, V_M_S 7370). Engineering sciences will be leverage to create a comprehensive study of orthopaedic biomechanics.  The tissue mechanics of bone and soft tissue will be studied along with applying structural analysis of the musculoskeletal system. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Applied Electronic Instrumentation
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7380). Fundamental concepts and theories, basic electronics, analog and digital circuits, signal conditioning, computer interfacing, measurement principles and techniques used in developing computer-based instrumentation systems.

courses.name: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 4420; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7420, PHYSCS 7420).  This course offers a broad introduction to medical imaging.  Topics to be covered include the physics basics and instrumentation of X-ray CT, PET , SPECT, ultrasound, MRI and Optical Imaging, as well as recent developments in biomedical imaging.

courses.name: Biomolecular Engineering and Nanobiotechnology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7470). Generation of biotechnological products, devices through integration of engineering approaches with contemporary biology, chemistry and nanotechnology starting at the molecular level.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 4190,CHEM 4490, NU_ENG 4319; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7480, PHYSIC 7190, CHEM 7490, NU_ENG 7319).  Physics and Chemistry of Materials is a 3 credit hours undergraduate/graduate level course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two mid term and one final exam. Graduate students will submit a term paper.

courses.name: Design of Livestock Waste Management Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7550). Development and application of design criteria to the design of agricultural waste management facilities.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1310 and CV_ENG 3700, MAE 3400 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Fluorescent Imaging
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7570). Principles and applications of fluorescent imaging. The course covers: Image formation in microscope; Fundamentals of fluorescence and fluorescent microscopy; molecular and cellular fluorescent imaging.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1500 and BIOL_EN 2180 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Computational Neuroscience
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 4580, ECE 4580; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7575, BIO_SC 7580, ECE 7580). An interdisciplinary course with a strong foundation in quantitative science for students in biological-behavioral sciences.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Mechanical Systems Engineering
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7580). Fundamentals and applications of prime movers and power transmissions for the design of engineering systems.
courses.hours: 3Corequisites: ENGINR 2100 or BIOL_EN 4380 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Photonics and Nanotechnologies in Optical Biosensors
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7670). Latest applications of photonics and nanotechnologies in optical bio-chemical sensors will be reviewed.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biomedical Optics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 7770). Essential concepts and methods for applying optical techniques to biomedical diagnosis and therapy will be covered with major application examples being discussed.

courses.name: Molecular and Cell Mechanics
courses.description: Application of mechanics and engineering principles to biological systems at the cellular and molecular levels. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Engineering Internship
courses.description: Problem course following prior approved work experience. Problem selected by internship company representative, faculty problem adviser and student. Supervised by faculty problem advisor and presented in engineering report form. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Biological Engineering Design
courses.description: Capstone design course for the Biological Engineering major. Design of biological system devices or processes.

courses.name: Biological Engineering Design - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Capstone design course for the Biological Engineering major. Design of biological system devices or processes.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Supervised independent study at the undergraduate level.

courses.name: Undergraduate Honors Research in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Open only to honor students in Biological Engineering. Independent investigation in biological engineering to be presented as a thesis.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Study of advanced developments in biological engineering.

courses.name: Bioelectricity
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4070). Application of engineering approaches to understand bioelectricity at the cellular level including the equivalent circuit of cell membranes and the electronic design of patch-clamp amplifiers.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 and BIOL_EN 3180 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Engineering Computation
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4080). An introduction to numerical methods relevant to biological engineering in the context of scientific computing.

courses.name: Soil and Water Conservation Engineering
courses.description: (same as CV_ENG 7710; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4150, CV_ENG 4150). Urban and rural run-off and erosion analysis. Design and layout of erosion control structures.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL_EN 2180 or CV_ENG 3200, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Food Process Engineering
courses.description: (cross-level with BIOL_EN 4160). Study of transport phenomena and unit operations in food processing systems. Emphasis on fluid flow and heat transfer in food processing, preservation processes, refrigeration, freezing, psychometrics, and dehydration.

courses.name: Biomaterials Interfaces of Implantable Devices
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4170). Surface structures and properties to improve biocompatibility will be studied.  Engineering sciences and design will be leverage in the design of an improved biocompatible surface.

courses.name: Transport Phenomena in Materials Processing
courses.description: (same as MAE 7231; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4231, MAE 4231). Applications of fluid flow, heat transfer, and mass transfer in steady-state and unsteady-state materials processing with applications to metals, polymers, and ceramics. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: MAE 3200, MAE 3400, MAE 4300 or equivalent; and MATH 4100

courses.name: Irrigation and Drainage Engineering
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4250). Soil, water, plant relationships. Water supplies and design of surface, sprinkler and drip irrigation systems. Surface and tile drainage.

courses.name: Food Process Engineering II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4260). Continuing study of transport phenomena and unit operations in food processing systems. Emphasis on fluid food evaporation concentration food dehydration, contact equilibrium processes and mechanical separation processes.

courses.name: Design of Experiments and Statistical Quality Control for Process Engineers
courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 7270; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4270, CH_ENG 4270).  A practical statistical tool box for experimenters including comparison of process means, effects of variables, design and interpretation of factorial experiments, and statistical quality control.
courses.prerequisites: experience with Excel or instructor's consent

courses.name: Feedback Control Systems
courses.description: (same as ECE 7310, MAE 7750; cross-leveled with ECE 4310, BIOL_EN 4310, MAE 4750). System modeling and time and frequency response, closed loop control, stability, continuous system design, introduction to descrete time control, software and hardware experiments on compensator design and PID control. Graded A-F only.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 7315; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4315, CH_ENG 4315).  This general introduction to bioprocess engineering covers the fundamentals of microbiology and biochemistry in the context of a biomass refinery.  Analysis proceed through the use of mass balances, energy balances, and empirical or theoretical models.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL_EN 2180 (for biological engineering students) or CH_ENG 2225 (for chemical engineering students) or instructor's consent

courses.name: Biomass Refinery Operation
courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 7316; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN  4316, CH_ENG 4316). Design and operation of processes for conversion and/or fractionation of biomass and associated upstream and downstream unit operations.  Emphasis on separations and product recovery.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL_EN 2180 or CH_ENG 2225 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Watershed Modeling Using GIS
courses.description: (same as CV_ENG 7720; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4350, CV_ENG 4720). Watershed evaluation using AVSWAT for hydrology, sediment yield, water quality; includes USLE, MUSLE, WEPP, Procedures for model calibration/sensitivity data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL_EN 2180 or CV_ENG 3200 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Orthopaedic Biomechanics
courses.description: (same as V_M_S 7370; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4370) . Engineering sciences will be leverage to create a comprehensive study of orthopaedic biomechanics. The tissue mechanics of bone and soft tissue will be studied along with applying structural analysis of the musculoskeletal system. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ENGINR 1200 and BIOL_EN 3170, instructor's consent required

courses.name: Applied Electronic Instrumentation
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4380). Fundamental concepts and theories, basic electronics, analog and digital circuits, signal conditioning, computer interfacing, measurement principles and techniques used in developing computer-based instrumentation systems.

courses.name: Introduction to Biomedical Imaging
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 7420; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4420, PHYSCS 4420).  This course offers a broad introduction to medical imaging.  Topics to be covered include the physics basics and instrumentation of X-ray CT, PET , SPECT, ultrasound, MRI and Optical Imaging, as well as recent developments in biomedical imaging, as well as recent developments in biomedical imaging.

courses.name: Biomolecular Engineering and Nanobiotechnology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4470). Generation of biotechnological products, devices through integration of engineering approaches with contemporary biology, chemistry and nanotechnology starting at the molecular level.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 7190, NU_ENG 7319, CHEM 7490; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4480, PHYSCS 4190, NU_ENG 4319, CHEM 7490).  Physics and Chemistry of Materials is a 3 credit hours undergraduate/graduate level course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two midterm and one final exam. Graduate students will submit a term paper.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 / CHEM 1320 or equivalent/prior approval by instructor

courses.name: Design of Livestock Waste Management Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4550). Development and application of design criteria to the design of agricultural waste management facilities.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1310 and CV_ENG 3700, MAE 3400 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Fluorescent Imaging
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4570). Principles and applications of fluorescent imaging. The course covers: Image formation in microscope; Fundamentals of fluorescence and fluorescent microscopy; molecular and cellular fluorescent imaging.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1500 and BIOL_EN 2180 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Computational Neuroscience
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 7580, ECE 7580; cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4575, BIO_SC 4580, ECE 4580). An interdisciplinary course with a strong foundation in quantitative science for students in biological-behavioral science. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Mechanical Systems Engineering
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_ENG 4580). Fundamentals and applications of prime movers and power transmissions for the design of engineering systems.
courses.prerequisites: Thermodynamics course, Fluid Mechanics courseCorequisites: ENGINR 2100 or BIOL_EN 7380 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Photonics and Nanotechnologies in Optical Biosensors
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4670). Latest applications of photonics and nanotechnologies in optical biochemical sensors will be reviewed. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biomedical Optics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIOL_EN 4770). Essential concepts and methods for applying optical techniques to biomedical diagnosis and therapy will be covered with major application examples being discussed.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 and BIOL_EN 3180; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Scientific Discovery Leading to Life Science Innovations
courses.description: (same as MPP 8000). The goal of this course is to provide participants with a conceptual and practical understanding of how life science research is conducted in a modern research institution in the US and the pathways involved in translating fundamental discoveries into products and services that affect healthcare. We will cover the transitions from initial discovery concepts to first-in-human studies, clinical trials, healthcare guidelines and policy to product development. We will provide an introduction to essential disciplines and interactions that enable scientific discoveries to move forward into novel device and drug therapies. Participants will come away with a very complete picture of how medical research happens, including: how it is funded; what is required to make discoveries and record and protect intellectual property that is created; how to advance innovations to clinical practice, how to navigate the regulatory and bioethical environment, and how discoveries reach practitioners and benefit patients. The Course is the first in a three course sequence leading to a Graduate Certificate in Life Science Innovation and Entrepreneurship. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Must be Graduate Standing or receive certificate program director's approval

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Study of advanced developments in biological engineering.

courses.name: Problems in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Supervised individual study at the graduate level.

courses.name: Seminar in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Recent investigations in biological engineering and related fields. Discussion of current literature; preparation and presentation of papers.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Student presentation and discussion of topical research. May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL_EN 8087 and BIOL_EN 8402 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Design and Development of Biomedical Innovations
courses.description: (same as ENGINR 8100). This course takes students through the process of brainstorming and working out a solution to a medical need, and then producing a product. Outputs may include the development of a physical prototype through interactions with the College of Engineering rapid prototype facility. The course is one of a three-course set leading to a Graduate Certificate in Translational Science and Entrepreneurship. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Student must be enrolled in a graduate degree program and enrolled in a sequenced cohort group beginning with MPP 8000/BIOL_EN 8000 then MPP 8100/BIOL_EN 8100 then MANGMT 8200

courses.name: Natural Systems for Wastewater Treatment
courses.description: Emphasis is on the design, management and biological performance of lagoons, overland flow systems and constructed wetland.
courses.prerequisites: CV_ENG 7230 and BIOL_EN 7150 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Sensors and Biosensors
courses.description: The course covers basic principles of chemical and biological sensors, such as immobilization techniques, transducers (optical, electrical, etc.) and performance factors.

courses.name: Numerical Methods in Engineering Research
courses.description: Numerical techniques and case studies in Biological Engineering. Topics include basic numerical methods, mathematical representation of data, matrix algebra, ordinary and partial differential equations.

courses.name: Advanced Ceramic Materials
courses.description: (same as CH_ENG 8230, MAE 8230). To provide an advanced level understanding between processing, properties, and microstructure of ceramic materials.  Topics include crystallography, defect chemistry, transport properties, microstructure, and forming methods.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Water Management Theory
courses.description: Advanced studies in erosion control, irrigation, and drainage. Water resources engineering.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1500, Computer Engineering and Computer Science course, SOIL 4307 or SOIL 7307 and Soil Conservation course

courses.name: Principles and Applications of Fluorescence
courses.description: Physical foundations of fluorescence, fluorophores, steady-state and lifetime measurements, and instrumentation. Applications in the life science from tissues staining to DNA probes.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Biological Transport Processes
courses.description: Principles of fluid flow, heat transfer, and mass transfer applied to (a) understanding of how the human body functions (from the cellular up to the system level) and (b) designing biomedical devices.  An independent project/case-study of a relevant research topic also required.

courses.name: Food Extrusion
courses.description: Engineering principles and applications of single and twin screw food cooking extrusion systems. Modeling, control and optimization of extrusion systems. Dough rheology.

courses.name: Materials Characterization Techniques
courses.description: Concepts and techniques in characterizing materials, including bulk and surface analyses.  Techniques are presented in terms of use, sample requirements, and the engineering principles.  Topics include: contact angle measurement, XPS, SEM, TEM, STM, AFM, XRD, and thermal analyses.
courses.prerequisites: at least one undergraduate course in material science, engineer, or design

courses.name: Modeling and Identification of Engineering Systems
courses.description: Generalized description of engineering systems, bond graph modeling, system identification techniques, and neural network approaches.

courses.name: Research Methods
courses.description: (same as F_S 8402). Review of literature; planning research projects; publication procedures.

courses.name: Ultrasensitive Biodetection
courses.description: Multiplexing single-molecule, single-cell, nanobiotech analytical techniques to improve disease diagnosis, treatment, and understanding of biophenomena (membrane transport, gene expression, enzyme activities, cell communications).  Graded A-F only.

courses.name: Microscopic Imaging
courses.description: Advanced topics in microscopic imaging with focus on applications of molecular and cellular imaging using fluorescent microscopy.

courses.name: Orthopaedic Failure Modes and Effect Analysis
courses.description: Engineering sciences will be leveraged provide a comprehensive study of failure modes and related effects for orthopaedic devices, orthopaedic tissue repair, and surgical interventions. Clinical case studies will be analyzed to introduce real world problems of orthopaedic failures. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL_EN 3170 or ENGINR 1200, BIOL_EN 4370 or BIOL_EN 7370 or instructor consent

courses.name: Photon Migration and Optical Imaging in Turbid Media
courses.description: The essential concepts and techniques in optical imaging in turbid media will be covered including both forward problems and inverse reconstruction theories. Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Molecular and Cell Mechanics
courses.description: Application of mechanics and engineering principles to biological systems at the cellular and molecular levels. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Masters Thesis Research in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Independent investigation to be presented as a thesis. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Biological Engineering
courses.description: Independent investigation to be presented as a thesis. Graded on S/U basis only.
